text: above ground it's a tube station like
any other but underground Clapham South
hides a warren of life-saving tunnels
preserved since the 1940s
so how deep underground are we going
we're going a hundred and twenty feet
down which is about a hundred and
seventy eight steps if we were taking
this deep level shelter was designed to
take in eight thousand people as bombs
were dropped over South London during
the Second World War you would have been
given an air-raid ticket which would
have told you where to come which
particular shelter to come to in which
particular bed these are the original
beds yes they've been down here for over
70 years now you know they're in pretty
good condition really considering the
tunnels would have been meant for people
across London to come to if there was a
public outcry at the beginning the war
because there was not enough adequate
deep sheltering for people so they had
to build these they had to build them
and they were all hand dug during the
war the original signs pointing the way
to the various dormitories are still
here dormitories which protected those
escaping bombs but unbelievably
dormitories which became temporary homes
for the immigrants invited to Britain
after the war these shelters also served
as accommodation for the people getting
off the Empire Windrush in 1948 from
Jamaica this is a picture of some of the
new arrivals who were registering here
at the labor exchange TfL along with the
London Transport Museum have now opened
up this piece of history for public
visits they say it's a good way to
generate much-needed income and that the
area will benefit from a cafe and
gallery space they may have been kept
hidden for decades but soon Londoners
can rediscover what went on in these
historic tunnels Alice bandook Ravi BBC
London News
